awd_titl_txt: Strategies of Influence and Persuasion in Legal Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Strategies of Influence and Persuasion in Legal Networks

Abstract:

Numerous participants are involved in the process of interpreting and shaping human rights law, including judges, court staff lawyers, policymakers, and advocacy organizations. By analyzing strategies of influence and dialogue that shape human rights law, this project will show how judgements at a human rights court are just one point in a larger process of influence and communication among several legal actors. Showing how legal decisions emerge through interactions among these different legal actors offers important information with respect to human rights law.

This project will focus on how the social interactions across a diverse network of legal actors shape the influence of the European Court of Human Rights, which draws together judges from 47 Council of Europe countries, hundreds of registry lawyers, and tens of thousands of individual applicants. The project will track strategies and concepts that these legal actors use to influence each other in processing applications, litigating cases, and delivering and executing judgements. In a mixed-methods study, the project will include interviews, participant observation, interactive mapping, and analysis of legal texts and judgements to analyze the mechanisms of language framing and circulation through which legal concepts become authoritative. By researching how social actors influence the scope and direction of international law while maintaining the integrity of domestic legal commitments, the project's findings will offer insight within a comparative legal framework of human rights law.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We are currently in an age of the “judicialization of politics.”  This means that people are increasingly turning to legal systems and courts to manage issues of political and democratic import. Given this, it is increasingly urgent to understand how such complex systems work, and what is gained or lost in using courts and legal institutions to address some of the world's most pressing political problems.

In the European context, activists, policymakers, legal practitioners and scholars  consider  the European Court of Human  Rights as one of the most successful human rights institutions in the world. Yet what “success” means is practice is much more difficult to track. This research project examined the meaning and experience of that ‘success,’ through an analysis of the everyday work of the Court among judges and lawyers. It also analyzed the reasons why human rights advocates turned to the European Court of Human Rights to advance claims for justice. Finally, it looked at the benefits and limits of the Court as a site of advocacy and action.

The project used interviews and participant observation to understand the intricate workings of a human rights institution that adjudicates binding legal decisions for over 800 million people in Europe. The resulting publications analyze the specific persuasive strategies, concepts and kinds of argumentation that legal actors use to influence each other in processing applications, litigating cases and delivering and executing judgements. In so doing, the work demonstrates that human rights actors, lawyers and judges frequently have different interpretations of what human rights law should be, how a human rights court ought to operate, and what justice ultimately looks like and means for different stakeholders. At times, these different perspectives and positions can make complex international institutions contradictory, confusing or unworkable. Yet despite these different, and at times competing approaches and interests, the research shows how people within and across the convention system manage to come to some mutual agreement and coordinated practice through which the ‘success’ of the institution is defined. This case study offers us a way to better understand both the possibilities and challenges of complex legal institutions, moving past a simplistic notion of success or failure in assessing justice initiatives.

Finally, the project also produced a database of the European Court of Human Rights caselaw and an easy to use, visually compelling web based mapping application. The app allows users to explore Court caselaw and its changing geographic scope and influence across Europe, over the past 50 years. This alternative visual method argues for new ways not only to theorize caselaw along time-space dimensions and highlights the importance of dynamic visualization as a supplement to written analysis.
